data: PED ED Glycogen Storage Disease Type 1

Glycogen storage disease type 1 (GSD 1) leads to excessive accumulation of glycogen and fat in liver, kidneys and intestinal mucosa.     Patients with GSD1 are at risk of developing severe hypoglycemia. They are completely dependent on a constant supply of dietary glucose to support blood glucose levels as they can not convert liver glycogen into glucose. They do NOT respond to IM glucagon administration. These patients are at risk of hypoglycemia even with short periods of fasting, when they are unable to eat, or are vomiting.  Patients presenting to ED who are unable to eat, have intractable vomiting, diarrhea, fever or infection, should be evaluated immediately with checking glucose level, and if oral/NG/G-tube feedings are not possible or not tolerated, start IV (D10WNS) immediately. Maintain glucose levels between 4.4 and 6 mmol/L.    Do NOT provide juice, popsicles, soda to GSD patients to increase glucose
